# Intro

## What is Atreyu?
Atreyu is an edge- and serviceworker- first framework for the most demanding personal web applications.

It supports real time data sync, offline usage and long lasting open tabs. Atreyu is made for a smooth transition from working prototype to production ready mission critical software and requires minimal boilerplate and only optional typings and schemas that can be gradually added as the project matures.

{{<Aside type="warning">}}
This is an early developer preview. The goal is to get early feedback and improve the developer experience and high level design. Expect changes of the API and stability issues.
{{</Aside>}}

## Where in the ecosystem does atreyu live?

> arch graphic

Atreyu combines aspects of three kinds of frameworks:<br>
- It is a meta framework like next.js or svelteKit bringing file system layout and routing as well as lifecycle and caching logic.
- It provides an answer to the data and request layer like apollo, react-query or tRPC, providing request batching, caching, (optional) data schema, service stitching as well as subscriptions
- It provides features from fullstack app platforms like hasura, AppSync or firebase like authentiction, user and session management, automatic database setup with live updates, edge functions, presence, deployments, logging and monitoring

On the dimension of static page vs web app, atreyu lies on the very end of 'web application framework'.

## Usecases
As a rule of thumb a project is perfect for atreyu if it either stores personal data like an email client or exposes a big dataset in an explorative way such as a map or an interface for population data.

A simple question to ask is if it makes sense to have sub-content of the app indexed by a public search engine or not. For example there is no situation in which you would have google index your email application or your bank data or in which a search engine would index all permutations of display parameters to graphs for an open data set. Below is a list of examples:

Personal Data Applications:
- Email Client
- Todo Application
- Calender
- Banking/ Accounting/ Finance App
- Health and Sports Data
- Messaging/ Chat
- Bookmark manager
- Personal Backup and Archive management
- File and Foto management apps
- Personal Notes
- Contacts Application
- Dashboards and Admin Interfaces
- Personal Data Stores for Web Service exports and backups
- Rich Editors for content that is published in other systems (eg. post editor for blog)

Data Explorer Applications:
- Maps Applications
- Open Data / Open Gov Explorers

If you are unsure please reach out we are always happy to give feedback if something is a good fit. Out goal is to provide a perfect solution to a relatively focused set of usecases, which allows us to make tradeofs supporting guarantees and features that would be very hard to acchieve otherwise.

## Relationship to other Projects and Compatibility

### Svelte, React, Vue
We love svelte and will deeply support this as UI library. It is not impossible we will support react, vue or whatever comes next, so, if you like atreyu and need to integrate it with another framework we will be happy to assist and provide support, we rather see an integrtion done right than giving a bad impression to all react or vue js users. Please reach out on [https://discourse](discourse).

Apart from svelte support in the build process, we provide a svelte router-store, the main atreyu datastore, as well as a few standard svelte components that can be used as needed. (eg. login screens, user menu, sidebar component, dev menu)

### Typescript
As the framwework matures, we strive to provide typescript support for all aspects. This includes not just typed APIs but also providing a way to automatically get types for everything described by schemas, so you do not have to rewrite or manyally sync types between frontend and backend.

### Node.js
We see nodejs as legacy software and the future of javascript in deno and edge runtimes such as cloudflare workers or vercel edge workers. However most node code should be possible to use fairly easy, especially if the code is compiled anyways and denos nodejs support grows stronger. However there are at least 3 different ways to use nodejs code, depending on the usecase and your project setup it is hard to give a general rule of thumb which one to pick. For example we use all 3 ways internally depending on the situation. In addition this is a highly dynamic environment and the exact guide would have to be updated every few months. The best way to get help or a guide would currently be to ask in the discord channel #nodejs and we will be happy to help. As soon as denos nodjs story is stabilized we will add a detailed guide here.

### GraphQL, Rest
Even though we provide the binding layer of your components to the datastore and first resolver layer, it is totally valid to make graphQL and Rest requests in the falcor handlers, in fact this is the main way to integrate external APIs, as a rule of thumb everything between the UI and the service worker is falcor, everything between the service worker and internal APIs is falcor or rest depending on how you want to work and external APIs or internal services in other frameworks can be integrated in whatever protocol they use, which is compleley transparent to your UI code. If you want to make CORS requests from the service worker handlers or proxy those requests in an edge handler is up to you, but we generally recomend proxying, as CORS setup can be often tricky and the system debugging and monitoring is very reduced when using a cors architecture. (as edge proxies can also add these requests to the tracing and logging)

### Cloudflare, Vercel, Deno deploy, Docker, Self Hosting
We aim to eventually support all runtimes that are part of the [Web-interoperable Runtimes Community Group](https://wintercg.org/), which includes deno deploy and vercel. However in the initial phase of atreyu we will focus on optimal cloudflare support, rather than having a few half baked runtime targets. One reason is that cloudflare is the most mature and powerful edge platform out there, another is that cloudflare has some added features that are central to atreyu and would need to be replaced with other implementations for a more generic deployment. The main one is cloudflares amazing fast and simple edge KV store, there is currently no obvious alternative for vercel edge functions or deno deploy. Self hosted and docker deployments will be made possible as soon as the community stabilizes a bit on what the runtime will be for running open source edge functions. Most cloudflare runtimes such as denoflare or wrangler are just meant for local previews, not production operation and deno has a few ways to implemnt such a system. In addition, cloudflare announced open sourcing the edge runtime, which could be a game changer depending how fast this will happen and open source adoption.

### Tailwind/ Windi CSS
We support tailwind style utility classes out of the box. Just use the style tag with postcss lang attribute:
```html
<style lang="postcss">
```
Currently no other postcss features or transformers are supported nor the api exposed. The same is true for svelte compile options. If you are missing any feature we are happy to add this to the framwork. Eventually plugins and arbitrary pipelines will be supported.

### Elastic
We love the elastic stack for APM and logging and want everyone to have the power and visibility that is provided by elasticsearch and kibana, rather than building a fancy but ultimately limited custom and internal solution like other hosters. If you really require an alternative please get in touch with us on discord or open a ticket.

### CouchDB/ Cloudant
We build the data side of offline and edge caching features as well as synchronisiation and live updates based on a version of couchdb replication. Of course it is possible to use any other database such as mongodb with native or added http interface similar to any other web service, but many advanced automatic features provided by atreyu would be not available or have to be reimplemented. If you have a specific need for an alternative system we are happy to hear the reasons and provide support.

### IPFS/ Web3
Atreyu aims to eventually support decentralized usecases. But unlike true web3 projects such as [fission](https://fission.codes) our main goal is to advance a bit more traditional web applications and only fully embrace ipfs and similar projects when it also improves web2 setups and does not add too much complexity for simple use cases. This means that the standard setup of atreyu does only use the content adressable storage aspect of ipfs and runs ipfs in offline mode without any P2P connectivity. This means we do not add the burden of P2P communication and warm up as other ipfs projects but also means normal atreyu apps work only with a DNS domain like any traditional web app. If you want to use atreyu with the real ipfs network, you currently cannot use edge functions, but need to run the complete backend inside the service worker.

### Websockets
Atreyu uses Server Sent Events for all realtime and live features. This has the benefit of much simpler operational complexity and a much simpler to reason about system in general. We also expose an API to sent your own custom messages in the multiplexed atreyu feed, which should be the best solution to nearly every problem that has a load of maximum 1 message every few seconds. Of course, for multiplayer features such as synchronising mouse or player positions of teams or streaming other continuous values, you can add your own websocket solution as in any other project.

## Why another framework
We want to build a true open source system, including the option to completely self host without any vendor lock in. This eliminates solutions like firebase, appSync, wrangler or vercel. Supabase is a project we like a lot but it is not an edge first system requiring complex service setups with kong, mutliple languages such as elixir services. In addition supabase does not embrace offline first applications or deep integration with the UI layer. We see offline first not just as a novelty for some applications that need offline features but as a fundamental way to optimize user experience with low latency and reliability. Some comparison missing? Let us know!

## Driving Values

## Goals and non-goals

atreyu does:
- build on svelte for rendering
	- write style with real css
	- write markup as close to real html as possible
	- compile components to self contained js files or web-components to build full apps or gradually enhance existing ones
	- fast and lightwight


- build on falcor for data and state management
	- initial data fetching
	- data updating
	- caching
	- request batching
	- garbage collection for cache / local state to control memory consumption
	- sync server and client state
	- retries and error handling
	- stitching different apis and microservices


- atreyu brings to the game (most features are totally optional):
	- integrating and binding data to UI state
	- offline first approach were apps are usable offline and sync data while online
	- eliminate glue code and setup
	- validation
	- testing
	- data mocking
	- auto rendering for data that has a schema
	- logging + events
	- routig
	- offloading data processing in web worker
	- endless scrolling
	- user management
	- connection to integrated websocket server with RPC protocol
	- introspection

currently out of scope or non-Goals
- Server Side Rendering or Search Engine Optimization
- Browser support before ES 6 Proxy Object Supported
- plugability or replacablility of svelte, webpack or falcor

## Motivation
Atreyu is intended to be run completely on edge servers with a 4 layer data-caching system (in tab memory, indexedDB via service worker, edge cache, db).
The atreyu backend currently runs on cloudflare worker infrastructure or in browser service workers, but this is likely to become the standard for edge workers, so google and others may be releasing compatible offerings next to cloudflare in the future.
